{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3489241,"name":"Alan Federman","username":"Ubiquity","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ubiquity/{size}/168857_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T21:32:57.824Z","cooked":"

I am trying to use the XRP with python on VS code on an Ubuntu 24 laptop. (no I am not a masochist, I am resource poor). I have python3, robot.py installed and the WPI installer run. When I try to create a new project, I only get java and cpp as language choices. I don’t see any xrp specific instances of code in extensions. In the example web page, language choice isn’t discussed. What am I missing?

If I remember, Python doesn’t have a link to WPILib extension directly. You’ll need to use py -3 -m robotpy init or python3 -m robotpy init in a terminal to initialize a RobotPy project.

Also, a XRP example project isn’t available yet

github.com/robotpy/examples

Add XRP reference example

opened 03:57AM - 07 Feb 24 UTC
virtuald

Would be good for someone to do this. Was done on https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/…using-robotpy-with-xrp/452186

I guess that the thread here could help you

Using RobotPy with XRP Technical
Want to use RobotPy with an XRP robot but having difficulty setting things up. In particular need to reference the XRPMotor class but that class is apparently not in wpilib. Where is it or is it accessible at all?

Seems a bit confusing. Following the tutorial, you get to create new Wpi project, and there isn’t a python option. I am an experienced with ROS, so I know about GitHub and can download examples. I am not seeing XRP development as a viable pathway to FRC vs code development.

I thought ROS learning curve was bad!

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-01-22T18:52:58.959Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":84,"readers_count":83,"score":21.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":482934,"topic_slug":"python-choice-not-found-in-wpi-project-create","display_username":"Alan Federman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":47943,"username":"megarubber","name":"Guilherme Samuel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/megarubber/{size}/172063_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24375,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/python-choice-not-found-in-wpi-project-create/482934/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3489959,"name":"Alan Federman","username":"Ubiquity","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ubiquity/{size}/168857_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-22T18:59:57.787Z","cooked":"

OK, I am a reasonably intelligent person. This is from the WPIlib docs:

Third party libraries are packaged into Python wheels and uploaded to PyPI (if pure python) and/or WPILib’s artifactory. Users can enable them as dependencies either by adding the component name to robotpy_extras (recommended) or by adding an explicit dependency for the PyPI package in requires . The dependencies are downloaded when robotpy sync is executed, and installed on the roboRIO when robotpy deploy is executed.

This isn’t just sloppy or lazy, it is infuriating. I have no idea what this means. If it is just say the name and it magically works, why not give an example so: For example to add the Rev dependencies do this…

I didn’t see how to add robotpy_extras anywhere.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-01-22T18:59:57.787Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":26.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":482934,"topic_slug":"python-choice-not-found-in-wpi-project-create","display_username":"Alan Federman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24375,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/python-choice-not-found-in-wpi-project-create/482934/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3489990,"name":"Guilherme Samuel","username":"megarubber","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/megarubber/{size}/172063_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-22T19:31:41.750Z","cooked":"
Ubiquity:

I didn’t see how to add robotpy_extras anywhere.

robotpy_extras is a part of pyproject.toml file, that comes when a new RobotPy project is initialized, and it’s necessary to update/control 3rd party or extra packages. Here’s the reference that show how the file works.

Speaking about XRP, the robotpy-xrp package probably is what you need to start. Put it in robotpy_extras, like this:

[tool.robotpy]
robotpy_version = "2025.X.X.X"
robotpy_extras = [
    "xrp"
]

If the reference doesn’t work, my suggestion is to place robotpy-xrp in requires section.

Also, you must not forget to install the package locally with py -3 -m pip install robotpy-xrp or python3 -m pip install robotpy-xrp.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-01-22T19:36:48.901Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":63,"readers_count":62,"score":27.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":482934,"topic_slug":"python-choice-not-found-in-wpi-project-create","display_username":"Guilherme Samuel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/python/pyproject_toml.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"pyproject.toml usage — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":47943,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/python-choice-not-found-in-wpi-project-create/482934/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3490639,"name":"Dustin Spicuzza","username":"virtuald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T14:12:55.254Z","cooked":"
Ubiquity:

This isn’t just sloppy or lazy, it is infuriating. I have no idea what this means.

The documentation is publicly editable. If you find it confusing, you should make a pull request to improve it.

Ubiquity:

If it is just say the name and it magically works, why not give an example so: For example to add the Rev dependencies do this…

Perhaps you forgot to read the preceding section, as it calls out exactly what is required to add to pyproject.toml for each dependency.

You are right that there isn’t an example of the toml on the page directly, but the “See also” in that preceding section links to a page with an example.

Once again, if you find this confusing, please make a pull request to fix it.

Ubiquity:

I thought ROS learning curve was bad!

I’m the primary person working on RobotPy development, and I simply don’t have enough time to do everything. Using RobotPy isn’t hard, but the documentation isn’t quite there yet because nobody has taken the time to do it. Community members need to step up and improve the documentation as they figure out how things work.

It sounds like you have a lot of valuable experience to contribute. I look forward to your future contributions!

I apologize for my tone. It seems though there is an assumption in the documentation that if you are trying to use Python, you are also know how to do FRC with Java and C++. For example it says to deploy code to the roborio. They is no mention that to deploy code you need an suitable Ethernet cable or network to connect to the RoboRio.

This is similar in ROS if you come from the Windows VS code world, lack of understanding Ubuntu is a major problem. I will endeavor to contribute. I did take a quick look at the github docs, but even after signing in, I could not post a comment or pull request.

I can’t seem to get commands2 installed:

_________________________ ERROR collecting robot.py ___________________________
ImportError while importing test module ‘/home/marcode/KitBotPythonCode/Inline Commands/robot.py’.
Hint: make sure your test modules/packages have valid Python names.
Traceback:
/usr/lib/python3.12/importlib/init.py:90: in import_module
return _bootstrap._gcd_import(name[level:], package, level)
robot.py:10: in
import commands2
E ModuleNotFoundError: No module named ‘commands2’

I see in the docs I need to add it, but I don’t see how to.

I think I have all the extensions. The docs are really unclear at what I need to do to get commands2

Thanks. I think I am getting close to getting it working, but I can’t imagine a FRC rookie adult or student getting as far as I have.

oops never mind:

pip3 install -U robotpy[rev]
robotpy[commands2]

But for big dummies like me, you need to have this in the docs.

Every time when I update RobotPy, I usually use the flag all to incorporate all 3rd party packages linked with WPILib system. So, you don’t need to reinstall one by one on your computer.

Windows: py -3 -m pip install robotpy[all]
Linux: python3 -m pip install robotpy[all]

Ubiquity:

I did take a quick look at the github docs, but even after signing in, I could not post a comment or pull request.

You can make contributions the same way that you contribute to any other github project. Fork the repo, make a branch, and open a pull request. Also see the contribution guidelines.

megarubber:

Every time when I update RobotPy, I usually use the flag all to incorporate all 3rd party packages linked with WPILib system. So, you don’t need to reinstall one by one on your computer.

I expect to get rid of robotpy[all] next year because you don’t have control over what particular versions of vendor libraries are installed (so you could have different versions on your robot and in your local environment, leading to inconsistencies). Instead, we should make the other ways of doing things more obvious and easier to use.

For more on that topic, see RFC: removing robotpy_extras components

I don’t recommend directly installing things via pip (other than robotpy), as that won’t download the correct libraries for deploying to the roborio.

The way this is supposed to work is for your robot project, you set up a pyproject.toml next to robot.py (you can use robotpy init for this). Then you set the desired robotpy_version and add the desired 3rd party libraries to pyproject.toml. After you do that, run robotpy sync and it will download and install all of the appropriate python packages for your PC and for the RoboRIO. When you do a robotpy deploy, it will check to see if your robot has the correct packages installed, and if not then it will use the packages it downloaded during sync to install them onto the roborio.

Currently there is ‘robotpy_extras’ and ‘requires’ in pyproject.toml… this is confusing, robotpy_extras will go away next year. requires is simply whatever you would add to pip install XXX – each item is the XXX.

If I was creating a robot project that needed commands and robotpy-rev, pyproject.toml would look like this:

[tools.robotpy]
robotpy_version = "2025.2.1.0"
robotpy_extras = ["commands2"]
requires = ["robotpy-rev ~= 2025.0.2"]

Then I would run robotpy sync to update my local environment and download roborio packages.

There needs to be better management tooling for updating pyproject.toml and making it more obvious how to add vendors and other libraries. In particular, there’s an assumption that you know how the python ecosystem works. There’s lots of room for improvement in the docs and in the implementation.

OK following the docs I downloaded and extracted the 2025 python pdf from the zip file:

3.3 Opening the 2025 KitBot Example
The 2025 KitBot example code is provided in individual zip files for each language on the KitBot
webpage. The Python code contains two complete projects which illustrate different ways of creating
Commands. Some description of the difference can be found in Error! Reference source not found.
below. To open the C++ code:
1. Download and unzip the Python example code. Make sure to unzip or copy to a permanent
location, not in a temporary folder.
2. Open WPILib VS Code using the Start menu or desktop shortcuts
3. In the top left click File->Open Folder and browse to the “C++” folder inside of the unzipped
example code, then open the desired one of the two example projects, and then click Select
Folder.

Since it talks about the C++ folder, I guess this is an oversight. I then see reference to two examples of code. I am assuming this means the “Traditional” and “Inline” folders? I next assume I need to adjust the Constants.py file to assign drive motors to actual PWM controllers, but if I hadn’t physically wired the robot how would I even know where to look to understand this?

It is too late to get this out there, but my ultimate goal is to get Python instead of Java to be the default FRC language.

Ubiquity:

I next assume I need to adjust the Constants.py file to assign drive motors to actual PWM controllers, but if I hadn’t physically wired the robot how would I even know where to look to understand this?

I’m not personally involved with the Kitbot guide, but my guess is that the physical assembly instructions tell you to build the robot in a particular way, so there is no need to change constants.py if you followed the build instructions as everything would be wired correctly. If you use CAN motors then you need to follow the separate configuration steps as detailed in the guide.
